instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.R6905: What is R6905? Resistor between charger voltage and input to PP3V42_G3H power supply on older Macbooks, pre-2011 models. This resistor blows when C6990 has shorted to ground or U6990 has shorted to ground, and will result in PP3V42_G3H missing and the magsafe charger not having a light since PP3V42_G3H is necessary for the SMC to turn on and the onewire circuit to turn on..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7051: What is R7051? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7050: What is R7050? Current sense shunt resistor for the battery, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 17/18 on ISL6259 should give you 2.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7052: What is R7052? Current sense resistor between battery current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
I am working on a late 2012 Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> I have the following with the board removed from the system and only the dc board attached.

Green light and then amber after a few seconds which means the PPV3v42 is working.

I measure the following
<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL> = 16.5V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 1.3v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> = 16.5V
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> = 16.5V

<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> = 10.03 ohms

<SIGNAL>CHGR_LGATE</SIGNAL> = switched output 
<SIGNAL>CHGR_UGATE</SIGNAL> = switched output

looking for suggestions on where to go next.

Thanks.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: Also there is no Fan spin

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
Is that <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board?

"<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> = 10.03 ohms"
Is that reading between pins 27/28 of <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>?
Post value for 17/18 too.

Also check voltage for some pins of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, 2, 3, 12, 13, 19, 20, 9, 15.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
I'm not sure where to find the 820 number,  the board has 2 fans.

yes on the 10.03 ohms

reading between pins 17/18 on <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> = 10.44 ohms

readings on pins

2 = 16.25
3 = 3.95
12 = 3.41
13 = 3.37
19 = 5.48
20 = 5.49

9,15  I can't locate another place on the board to get readings on this and I don't have a probe small enough to get those.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: Resistance to ground on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: 8.8 ohms measured at <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> to ground with power disconnected.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
You didn't specify which pin of <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR>.
Remove F7040 and see where the short remains.

"17/18 on <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> = 10.44 ohms"
You must get aprox 3 ohms there.

"yes on the 10.03 ohms"
And aprox 20 here; no idea how you measure on the board.

Take readings on the <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/50 directly.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: You?re like measuring 17/18 and 27/28 improperly but we?ll worry about that soon. Remove F7040 and see if the short is on pin 1 or pin 2

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
the measurement for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was taken from pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR>

This measurement 
 "<RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> = 10.03 ohms"  was taken from pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> to pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> with the resistors in series 10 ohms + .02 ohms + 10 ohms = 10.02 ohms so my 10.03 ohms reading seems to be in tolerance.

"17/18 on <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> = 10.44 ohms"  this was take from pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> to pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR>   the schematic shows <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> as 2.2 ohms + <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> .01 + <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> as 0 (??) =  2.21 ohms   I am reading 10.44 on a second reading of that I'm showing 10.63 now.

I will remove F7040 and check for the short and report back.

Thanks

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
"10 ohms + .02 ohms + 10 ohms = 10.02 ohms"
Really NOT; 20.02 ohms if you want be so exact.
With a reading of aprox 20 ohms is OK.

"17/18 on <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> = 10.44 ohms"
Now measure <RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR>/52 separatelly and change the one with higher value.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
ha yea your right, what was I thinking?

what temp do you guys use for these boards to remove, I had mine set to 380c and was able to remove some components from a test board but this fuse doesn't seem to want to come loose?

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: I rechecked the reading at <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR> = 20.02    not sure what I did before.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
Add first leaded solder on its terminals...

Temp adjust depend by every hot air station.
I use Mlink H1 at 475 degrees and 5 air flow.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
Thanks the leaded solder did the trick!
<RESISTOR>R7051</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7052</RESISTOR> + <RESISTOR>R7050</RESISTOR> =  3.3 OHMS now

short to ground now appears on pin 2 of the fuse F7040

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
measurement from pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> to ground is 8.9 ohms  pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> to ground is 18.9 ohms

from the schematic I have there isn't anything between pin 2 of F7040 and pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR>

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
Nothing more than the same name, =<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; what do you think this mean?
Impossible to draw all the connections in the same page for a mainboard...

So you have aprox 9 ohms on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, which is main power rail.
Check now for a similar value on the big coils (secondary supplies).
If you get same value on any, check then resistance between that coil and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. A reading close to 0 ohm will mean the high-side MOSFET of respective power supply is shorted.
Do NOT inject tension into <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> before check all of them.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
I removed F9700  and short remains
I had also removed <RESISTOR>R6905</RESISTOR> I'm not sure If I had said that in the last post.

Checked the following  TO <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>

L7030 P1 448.2 ohms
L7220 P1 2.93 k ohms
L7550 P1 12.3 ohms
L7560 P1 12.3 ohms
L7510 P1 14.5 ohms
L7520 P1 14.5 ohms
L7630 P1 25.2 ohms

I attached the power supply and I am now getting 12v at pin 1 of F4070 while its removed.

I guess the next suggestion will be to inject power and see what heats up?

Thanks

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: If the short is on pin 2 of the fuse, it could be several things. Inject voltage at pin 2 start low around 1 volt to make sure it is not the CPU. Commonly, large caps can cause your short.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
Do NOT inject tension before you check what I mentioned before.
NEVER ever inject voltage on the main power rail before discard a shorted high-side MOSFET!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
I had removed F9700 before your post I was just letting you know what I did.

these were the measurements from the coils to ground

Reading to ground

L7030 = changing in the mega ohms
L7510 = 5.6 ohms
L7520 = 5.6 ohms
L7550 = 3.3 ohms
L7560 = 3.3 ohms
L7630 = 16 ohms

after that I measured the following to <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> since these were closer to 0 ohms

[LEFT][COLOR=#353535][FONT=Arial][SIZE=12px]L7560 P1 12.3 ohms

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: Check resistance between pin 2 of the fuse and L7510.

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message: pin2 of fuse to p1 of L7510 is 14.4 ohms

threads.title: Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> logic board
threads.message:
You have more coils to check, look schematic from page 57 to 63.
If between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and one coil you get the sum of both resistances to ground, that means its high side MOSFET is OK.
Where you will get the difference, then remove its MOSFET and check resistance to ground again.
